docs.snippet: The 143-foot seagoing tug Leon, formerly the ATA 170, is now en route to Piraeus, Greece, by way of the Canal Zone, officials of the Moran Towing  Transportation Company reported yesterday. At the Canal Zone, they explained, the tug will take in tow...
docs.lead_paragraph: The 143-foot seagoing tug Leon, formerly the ATA 170, is now en route to Piraeus, Greece, by way of the Canal Zone, officials of the Moran Towing Transportation Company reported yesterday. At the Canal Zone, they explained, the tug will take in tow two sixtyton floating derricks brought down from Seattle, Wash.
docs.abstract: GREECE: buys equipment from US to rebuild war-damaged docks

headline.main: 3 DERRICKS BOUGHT IN U.S. BY GREEKS; Tug, Also Purchased to Aid in Repair of Ports, Will Tow 2 to Piraeus

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Week Ended May 29, 1947 Interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered for the most part in the irregularity of the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland. Elsewhere spot sterling was steady but forwards continued weak at widening...
docs.lead_paragraph: Week Ended May 29, 1947 Interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered for the most part in the irregularity of the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland. Elsewhere spot sterling was steady but forwards continued weak at widening discounts. Other Europeans were lightly traded at no important change in rate.

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 2 -- Emil Sandstroem, Sweden's representative on the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, was elected chairman of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine today. The ballot, a secret one, was the first of...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 2 -- Emil Sandstroem, Sweden's representative on the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, was elected chairman of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine today. The ballot, a secret one, was the first of three important votes by the committee.
docs.abstract: Elected UN Palestine inquiry com vp

headline.main: U.N. PALESTINE UNIT HEADED BY SWEDE; Sandstroem, Jurist, Is Elected Inquiry Chairman -- Decision on Visits to DP's Put Off

byline.original: By GEORGE BARRETTSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: The return of the "Good Neighbor Fleet" to peacetime passenger service between New York and the east coast of South America was announced yesterday by Moore-McCormack Lines. The first sailing will be made on July 25 by the reconverted liner...
docs.lead_paragraph: The return of the "Good Neighbor Fleet" to peacetime passenger service between New York and the east coast of South America was announced yesterday by Moore-McCormack Lines. The first sailing will be made on July 25 by the reconverted liner Argentina.
docs.abstract: July sailing set; illus; Capt Simmons re-assigned command

headline.main: ARGENTINA SAILING SLATED FOR JULY 25; First of Three Sister Ships to Resume 'Good Neighbor' Runs to South America

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Former Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana resigned today as special counsel for the Senate War Investigating Committee. He was named several weeks ago to handle an investigation of Government purchases of oil from the...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Former Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana resigned today as special counsel for the Senate War Investigating Committee. He was named several weeks ago to handle an investigation of Government purchases of oil from the Arabian Gulf area.
docs.abstract: B K Wheeler resigns as War Investigating Com special counsel

headline.main: WHEELER QUITS POST AS OIL INQUIRY WAITS

docs.snippet: WITH 34,000,000 workers in the United States now receiving paid vacations, plus the thousands of people who do not have to rely on such considerations when going on holiday, indications are that 1947 travel figures in the Western Hemisphere will top...
docs.lead_paragraph: WITH 34,000,000 workers in the United States now receiving paid vacations, plus the thousands of people who do not have to rely on such considerations when going on holiday, indications are that 1947 travel figures in the Western Hemisphere will top last year's by 25 to 30 per cent.
